/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Should we mark grub2 as deprecated if this goes through?

It feels weird to be using the bootloader element to not install a bootloader.  But if it means we effectively drop another fairly bespoke path for this in a more generic sense, it's probably worth it.

I know I voted on this before, but I'm just really uncomfortable making the bootloader path do this -- it warns that no bootloader will be installed then the next thing that comes out of it is "Installing GRUB2"

But I had a thought, instead of taking this path on the default, could we make a block-device-pre-partitioned or something, and keep this behind that?  I feel like with that, we're at least keeping it on a separate path that we can reason about?

Sorry, I should have reviewed this earlier.  I'm still a bit worried about reducing it to a warning, but practically I can't see anyone using this element outside the context of also using the "vm" element, so perhaps that is not warranted

diskimage_builder/elements/bootloader/fi.message: Actually this path needs to behave more like the grub2 element, and install the grub-efi things also. Since something else is installing bootloader and there is no way here to know if its legacy BIOS or UEFI, so lets prepare for both

How about moving everything from here on to a new element which both bootloader and grub2 depend on? And it only executes when a variable is set, so bootloader always runs it but grub2 only runs it if the user chooses to?

I still don't really like turning a hard error into a warning that likely nobody will read.  But going back through things, the main way into this is adding the "vm" element, and we have backwards compatibility in there that sets "block-device-mbr" by default if you haven't included a block-device anyway.  So it's probably the case that practically you can't fall in here without setting this.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message: This one seems too broad - there might be not only "drop" flows matched
That one is for the case when port's tag is changed which seems quite a rare case. Anyway I believe adding priority and table_id to the matching filters should be safer

Sure, make sense. Commit c54c5791b43deada9936f0c9c5d8b681a3216893 was a work around fix for test_update_instance_port_admin_state, it can work is because of the action of uninstall flow on line 1213, removing all in_port related flows and all flows will be re-installed in the following procedures. But that may have a side effect is it may take long time for port to get link ready. Tests show that if port admin state is down, the installed flows are still there for the ofport. So a strict flow removing should be fine.

@Oleg
I have another case, sometimes in cloud operation and maintenance, operators may use port admin state DOWN/UP to fix some potential flow miss or wrong flows. They want to delete all ports related flows after set it to DOWN state, and refresh them all after UP. If we do strict delete for the block flow on table=0 only, some stale flows may remain. What do you think?
Actually it is what ovs-agent done before, see line 1213, a story introduced by this commit c54c5791b43deada9936f0c9c5d8b681a3216893.

I think these two methods (port_alive, port_dead) should operate same flows, and hence be consistent with each other. If port_alive() uninstalls all flows, even not related to dropping - that doesn't sound safe and reliable to me.

deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-pack.message: Will this work with leapp < leapp-upgrade-el7toel8-0.16.0 ? What happens if /etc/leapp/files/device_driver_deprecation_data.json does not exist?

The patch was tested with old and new leapp. 

In old leapp /etc/leapp/files/device_driver_deprecation_data.json doesn't exist so we'll just create empty file which won't be used anyway. Even if it exists /usr/share/leapp-repository/repositories/system_upgrade/el7toel8/actors/kernel/checkkerneldrivers/files/removed_drivers.txt will be used which is processed as well.

In new leapp /etc/leapp/files/device_driver_deprecation_data.json is downloaded with all data we need to remove.

test_user_update_own_password and test_password_history_check_self_service_api tests are failing only under one specific condition - keystone on the tested environment is set with a minimum password age before it can be changed again (minimum_password_age = 1 within keystone.conf) - https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1946459

If minimum_password_age = 1, then a user's password can be changed only once per day, not more, however, those tests require 2 password changes - first one to verify that we can change the password (that's the purpose of the test) and the second one is to revert the password back so that other tests which use the same test user can proceed.

There has been an attempt to solve this by passing certain parameters to the request which creates a test user - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/806671/1/tempest/lib/services/identity/v3/users_client.py - the problem with that was that the patch modified a client which means that all tests (in tempest or in any tempest plugin) would be affected by that - that could raise unwanted effects. The idea should be to modify (by passing those params) only the test user created for those 2 specific tests. So we should find a way how to pass the params introduced in 806671 from the test scope, not globally from the client's perspective.

tempest/api/identity/v3/test_users.py.message:
this if can't be deleted, the restore_password functionality can tested only if tempest.conf contains:

[identity-feature-enabled]
security_compliance = True

The same applies on test_user_update_own_password and test_password_history_check_self_service_api tests. Those will be skipped by tempest if user sets the security_compliance to False in the tempest.conf - that might be handy for some users.

roles/tripleo_ceph_deploy/defaults/main..message: do we want to default to "ceph" here?

I thought about it but decided not to.

As per [1], if left unset `openenstack overcloud ceph deploy` will default this value to 'ceph'.

So it is getting defaulted to "ceph", but because of a default in python-tripleoclient instead of because of a default in tripleo-operator-ansible. When it's left unset, the command which is generated doesn't container "--cluster ceph" which is simpler. It also allows us to not have to update the default in tripleo-operator-ansible. It's a pattern (leaving default variables unset) I see in other roles in tripleo-operator-ansible.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-operator-ansible/+/835377/1/roles/tripleo_ceph_deploy/README.md#15

roles/tripleo_ceph_deploy/tasks/main.yml.message: Because this is undefined by default, ternary results in it getting set to '' by default. Otherwise, when it's defined it gets assigned the env variable $CLUSTER on line 46 and that same var is passed to --cluster when the command is run.

ci/environments/multinode-containers.yam.message:
Unfortunately current puppet doesn't allow this usage.

oslo::log is not a class but a resource type. All parameters passed to the resource type should be defined in a class which declares a resource using the resource type. So we should use parameters of each *::log classes (eg nova::logging, cinder::logging), or we need to implement a logic in puppet-tripleo which picks up this hieradata key and pass the value to the corresponding class parameters of *::logging class.
Thank you Takashi-san, I've totally missed (again!) that that's a definition, not a class.

The required steps here are;

* Add a new parameter in oslo.log
* Update oslo::log to support the new parameter
* Update the *::logging class in individual modules to expose the new parameter and set the parameter of oslo::log resource type.

Then

* Add puppet parameters for individual modules here

or 

* Implement a logic to pick up common hieradata key and set *::logging::log_global_request_id
* Use that specifial hieradata key in tht

though honestly I don't recommend the second approach, to avoid implementing more logic in puppet manifest considering less people and less interest to maintain it.

neutron/policy.py.message:
According to the description and [1], this problem is only present when do_raise=False. Why do we need this here?

[1]https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.policy/+bug/1965315

this is "enforce" function which we want to check policy and raise an exception if that's the case. Such exception is then logged and returned to the user in API response.
Above, in the "check" method which just want to check if user have or don't have access to something. And based on that result return some API response.
Both methods are used e.g. in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1473adca5d9fb5832c29694a3a93c5b5e9262b0b/neutron/api/v2/base.py#L584 so it may give You better idea how it works and what's the difference between them
Gotcha. This is related to LP#1959333, not the oslo.policy bug. Sorry for mixing both errors.

This means that InvalidScope exception is raised to the API layer, but the API layer handles only PolicyNotAuthorized (for example, [1] and [2]).
I think we need to handle InvalidScope. (or we can raise PolicyNotAuthorized even when InvalidScope is caught here. I am not sure which is better right now though.)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1473adca5d9fb5832c29694a3a93c5b5e9262b0b/neutron/api/v2/base.py#L588
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1473adca5d9fb5832c29694a3a93c5b5e9262b0b/neutron/pecan_wsgi/hooks/policy_enforcement.py#L137
You're right. I just updated this patch and proposed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/835234

In addition, PolicyNotAuthorized is sometimes not caught explicitly in the API layer (neutron/api/v2 and pecan_wsgi). For such cases, PolicyNotAuthorized is coverted into a general HTTP exception by neutron.api.api_common.convert_exception_to_http_exc(). PolicyNotAuthorized is registered in [1]. If we raise InvalidScope from enforce(), perhaps we need to add an entry to [1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/74d3765407de58fcf871f7de48aaed544feedabf/neutron_lib/api/faults.py#L27

This bug caused a failure in subcloud deployment based on the launchpad description. Yet I don't see subcloud deployment test as part of the test plan.

Hi Tee.
There was a discussion about the Test Plan covered by this fix. Since this is a bug that requires to be fixed ASAP, we can reduce the Test Plan to only ensure that the rvmc pod is running on a Standard system (that has the master node taint enabled).
The error message on launchpad describe that the pod is not able to run because it doesn't tolerate the taint. This change only adds the toleration for that taint (making the pod able to run on STD systems), and does not do anything internal to the container. So, RVMC functionality test is not needed. 

Are you ok with this? If the test plan includes subcloud deployment, this can take several weeks to get the specific hardware in order to do it.

Thank you

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: It would be good to know when that would be useful. The pod type is made to simulate a regular instance where zuul can execute job similarly to the other nodes provided by openstack or aws. Thus the pod should not be doing anything else than waiting for the ansible driven exec call.

The main reason for this change would be avoiding errors like "Failed to get D-Bus connection" and similar since Init process is not spawned with PID 1 and the container is not created with privilege mode within K8s driver. However, since we used a script to simulate systemctl this change or other changes on pods creation specs are not necessary anymore.

doc/source/kubernetes.rst.message:
Reading these new docs it isn't clear to me what the old behavior was and why it is useful.

Looking more closely I believe the intent was that the container would be started in a pod then told to sit idle while the rest of the job connected to it and directed it to do work. Knowing this it might be better to set this up as a single flag something like:

   .. attr:: override-container-command
      :type: bool
      :default: True

      Only used by the :value:`providers[kubernetes].pools.labels.type.pod`
      label type. The default behavior is to run "/bin/sh -c 'while true;
      do sleep 30; done;'" in the container forcing it to idle except for
      the tasks run against the container by your job definition. This can
      be set to false if you would prefer to run the container's default
      CMD value instead.

Then don't bother with override-container-args. Basically make this a single toggle and make it more clear why one might want to set it.
